Articles.Content:
Ladies and kerbalmen, I present the K-6 Cormorant.

> ![sTRFR.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/sTRFR.jpg)

> ![6wkR6.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/6wkR6.jpg)

> ![nLvOK.png](http://i.imgur.com/nLvOK.png)

The Cormorant uses 3 sets of powerful propellers each powered by an individual engine, with a main one in the middle and 2 weaker ones on twin booms to the side of the plane, hence giving it a '2 planes ducttaped together' appearance to some. It has a max speed of over 370 m/s below 5000 meters, highly maneuverable and easy to take off with. If in moments of distress, the twin booms can simply be decoupled from the plane (I don\'t know why you\'d want to do this, it\'s just kerbal I guess) to let the cockpit freefall and crash glide softly to a landing. It was modeled very *roughly* like the P-38 Lightning.
I normally reserve the names of large birds for large craft.
I don\'t consider the albatros too large of a bird neither do I consider the plane too small, but I changed it.

> 
> I don\'t consider the albatros too large of a bird neither do I consider the plane too small, but I changed it.

An Albatross is a seagoing bird with a very wide wingspan.

I know, but overall they\'re about as big as a goose.

Anyways I think the name is of minimal importance.
